revision.comment: Herodotus says he drank the blood of a bull in the source provided
revision.text:
{{Infobox military conflict | conflict = Battle of Pelusium | partof = | image = Cambyses II capturing Psamtik III.png | image_size = 300 | caption = [[Cambyses II]] of Persia capturing pharaoh [[Psamtik III]] after his conquest of Egypt. Image on Persian seal, 6th century BC. | date = May 525 BC | place = [[Pelusium]], [[Egypt]] | casus = | territory = Egypt annexed by the Achaemenid Empire | result = [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] victory{{sfn|Bang|Scheidel|2013|p=201}} | combatant1 = [[Twenty-sixth dynasty of Egypt|Kingdom of Egypt]]
[[Caria]]n mercenaries
[[Ionia]]n mercenaries | combatant2 = [[Achaemenid|Achaemenid Empire]]
[[Arabian]] allies
Defected [[Greeks|Greek]] mercenaries | commander1 = [[Psamtik III]] (Psammenitus){{POW}} | commander2 = [[Cambyses II]] | strength1 = Unknown | strength2 = Unknown | casualties1 = 50,000 ([[Ctesias]]) | casualties2 = 7,000 ([[Ctesias]]) }} [[File:Meeting Between Cambyses II and Psammetichus III.jpg|thumb|250px|Meeting Between Cambyses II and [[Psammetichus III]], as imaginatively recreated by the French painter [[Adrien Guignet]]]] The '''Battle of Pelusium''' was the first major battle between the [[Achaemenid Empire]] and [[Twenty-sixth Dynasty of Egypt|Egypt]]. This decisive battle transferred the throne of the [[Pharaoh]]s to [[Cambyses II]] of [[Persia]]. It was fought near [[Pelusium]], an important city in the eastern extremes of [[Egypt]]'s [[Nile Delta]], 30 km to the southeast of the modern [[Port Said]], in 525 BC. The battle was preceded and followed by sieges at [[Gaza City|Gaza]] and [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]]. ==Background== ===Herodotus on motives and background=== The best recounting of the events leading to the battle of Pelusium is from [[Greek historians]], particularly [[Herodotus]]. According to Herodotus the conflict between the Pharaoh [[Amasis II]] of Egypt and Cambyses II of Persia was a gradual process involving multiple personalities, mostly Egyptians. According to Herodotus, an Egyptian physician was requested by Cambyses from Amasis on good terms, to which Amasis complied. The physician (most likely an ancient [[ophthalmologist]]) resented the forced labor that Amasis had imposed on him, and in retaliation, persuaded Cambyses to ask of Amasis a daughter in marriage, knowing how Amasis would dislike losing his daughter to a Persian. Cambyses complied, requesting the hand of the daughter of Amasis in marriage. Amasis, unable to let go of his offspring, and unwilling to start a conflict with the Persians, instead sent an Egyptian girl named [[Nitetis]], who was a daughter of an Egyptian named [[Apries]]. According to Herodotus, Apries was the previous pharaoh whom Amasis had defeated and killed, and whose daughter was now to be sent in place of Amasis's own offspring. Once greeted by Cambyses as "the daughter of Amasis", Nitetis explained the trickery employed by Amasis to avoid giving away his own daughter to the king. This infuriated Cambyses, who vowed to avenge the insult.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1uQaAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA245&dq=Herodotus+Amasis&hl=en&ei=a0o0Tb-HMdDegQfu64niCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&sqi=2&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Herodotus%20Amasis&f=false|title=The History of Herodotus Volume I, Book II|author=Herodotus|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=246–250}} According to Herodotus, another motivation that solidified Cambyses's expedition into Egypt was [[Phanes of Halicarnassus]]. Originally a council man and advisor to Amasis, an unknown course of events led to bitterness developing between them to the point that Amasis sent an Egyptian [[eunuch]] after Phanes, pursuing him to [[Lydia]]. Phanes was captured in [[Lycia]] but outwitted his guards by getting them drunk and escaped to Persia, and assisted the Persian king in all manners of strategy, and was instrumental in shaping his resolve for conquest of Egypt. Despite having full control over the [[Neo-Babylonian empire]] and its sub-regions including northern Arabia, Cambyses sent a message to the King of Arabia requesting safe passage through the desert road from Gaza to Pelusium. The Arabian king, himself an enemy of Amasis, and glad to facilitate his destruction, granted safe passage to Cambyses and even supplied him with troops. According to [[Polybius]], even with all the precautions taken on entering the border of Egypt, only the city of Gaza resisted the Persians, which fell after a long siege. When the news of the impending battle reached Egypt, [[Psamtik III]] (Psammenitus), son and heir of Amasis II, gathered the Egyptian army, stationing it along the fork of the [[Red Sea]] and the river [[Nile]]. Amasis himself died six months before Cambyses reached Egypt.{{cite book|title=Manners and customs of the ancient Egyptians: including their private life, government, laws, art, manufactures, religions, and early history; derived from a comparison of the paintings, sculptures, and monuments still existing, with the accounts of ancient authors. Illustrated by drawings of those subjects, Volume 1|author=Sir John Gardner Wilkinson|publisher=J. Murray|year=1837|pages=195|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YLZjAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA195&dq=death+of+Amasis+Herodotus&hl=en&ei=Z040TaXbCIW0lQe077S2Cg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFMQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=death%20of%20Amasis%20Herodotus&f=false}} Psamtik had hoped that Egypt would be able to withstand the threat of the Persian attack by an alliance with the [[Greek city states|Greeks]], but this hope failed, as the Cypriot towns and the tyrant [[Polycrates of Samos]], who possessed a large fleet, now preferred to join the Persians. That one of Egypt's most prominent tactical advisers, Phanes of Halicarnassus, had already gone over to the Persian side meant that Psamtik was entirely dependent on his own limited military experience. Polycrates sent 40 [[triremes]] to the Persians. Psamtik, in a violent act of revenge prior to the confrontation with the Persian army, arrested all the sons of Phanes and stood them between two bowls. He then cut them one by one, draining their blood and mixing it with wine. Psamtik then drank of it and made every other councilman drink their blood before the battles. ==The battle== [[File:MarchofCamybsesII.png|thumb|right|The possible path of Cambyses, Phanes of Halicarnassus, and Amasis's forces sent after Phanes; Note: The itinerary paths depicted are supposed and by no means certain. Persian forces - black line, Phanes of Halicarnassus - blue line, and Egyptians - red line.]] The decisive military conflict happened at Pelusium. As Herodotus describes a sea of skulls at the Nile basin, upon the remnants of which he remarks on the differences between the Persian and the Egyptian heads. According to [[Ctesias]], fifty thousand Egyptians fell, whereas the entire loss on the Persian side was only seven thousand. After this short struggle, the troops of Psamtik fled, and soon the retreat became a complete rout. Disoriented, and fleeing, the Egyptians took shelter in [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]]. The Egyptians were now besieged in their stronghold of Memphis. ==Aftermath== According to Herodotus, Cambyses, in a last attempt to bring an end to the struggle, sent a Persian herald in a ship to exhort the Egyptians to give up before further bloodshed. Upon sighting the Persian vessel at the port of Memphis, the Egyptians ran out, attacking the ship and killing every man in it, carrying their torn limbs with them back to the city. As Cambyses advanced to Memphis, it is said that for every [[Mytilene|Mytilenian]] killed during the siege of Memphis, ten Egyptians died, which makes the number of dead Egyptians two thousand, who may have been executed at the time or after the siege, because two hundred Mytileneans were killed. Pelusium probably surrendered itself immediately after the battle. The pharaoh was captured after the fall of Memphis and allowed to live under Persian watch. He later commited suicide after attempting a revolt against the Persians. ==Herodotus on the battle== [[File:Le roi Cambyse au siège de Péluse par Paul-Marie Lenoir.jpg|thumb|300px|According to [[Polyaenus]], the Persian soldiers allegedly used cats - among other sacred Egyptian animals - against the Pharaoh's army. Paul-Marie Lenoir's paintwork, 1872.]] The fields around were strewn with the bones of the combatants when [[Herodotus]] visited. He noted that the skulls of the Egyptians were distinguishable from those of the Persians by their superior hardness, a fact confirmed he said by the mummies, and which he ascribed to the Egyptians' shaving their heads from infancy, and to the Persians covering them up with folds of cloth or linen. [[Polyaenus]], "a retired Macedonian general more interested in novelty than historical accuracy",Katharine M. Rogers, ''The Cat and the Human Imagination: Feline Images from Bast to Garfield'', University of Michigan Press, 2001, pp. 14 claims that, according to legend, Cambyses captured Pelusium by using a clever strategy. The Egyptians regarded certain animals, especially cats, as being sacred (they had a cat goddess named [[Bastet]]), and would not injure them on any account. Polyaenus claims that Cambyses had his men carry the "sacred" animals in front of them to the attack. The Egyptians did not dare to shoot their arrows for fear of wounding the animals, and so Pelusium was stormed successfully. This would be an early form of [[psychological warfare]].{{cite journal|author1=New York (State). Dept. of Mental Hygiene|journal=Psychiatric Quarterly: Supplement, Volumes 24-25|date=1950|page=281|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b_M6AAAAIAAJ|publisher=State Hospitals Press}} Herodotus, however, makes no mention of any such strategy, and "gives hardly any information" about the fighting in general. According to Herodotus, Cambyses initially behaved with a certain moderation, sparing the son of Psamtik due to feeling "a touch of pity",{{cite book|last1=Briant|first1=Pierre|title=From Cyrus to Alexander: A History of the Persian Empire|date=2002|publisher=Eisenbrauns|isbn=9781575061207|page=54|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lxQ9W6F1oSYC&lpg=PA54|language=en}} but later, dissatisfied with his victory and unable to punish the already deceased Amasis for his trickery, decided to commit what Herodotus calls an un-Persian act: he desecrated the tomb of the mummified Amasis and ordered the mummy burned. However, [[Pierre Briant]] concludes that Herodotus' recorded information regarding Cambyses' actions in Egypt after the victory is false.{{cite book|last1=Briant|first1=Pierre|authorlink=Pierre Briant|title=From Cyrus to Alexander: A History of the Persian Empire|date=2002|publisher=Eisenbrauns|isbn=9781575061207|page=57|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lxQ9W6F1oSYC&lpg=PA57|language=en}} Cambyses then made peace with Libyans, accepting their offer for truce. Egypt became a possession of Persia, and Cambyses its Pharaoh. Because they defeated the pharaohs of the twenty-sixth dynasty, Persian monarchs were acknowledged as pharaohs and came to be known as Egypt's [[Twenty-seventh Dynasty of Egypt|Twenty-seventh Dynasty]] (or the first Persian period). ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== * Herodotus.'' The Histories''. Suffolk, England: Penguin Books, 1975. * Dupuy, R. Ernest, and Trevor N. Dupuy. ''The Encyclopedia of Military History from 3500 BC. to the present''. New York: Harper and Row, 1977. * Fuller, J.F.C. ''A Military History of the Western World'', Volume One. N.P.: Minerva Press, 1954. * Harbottle, Thomas. ''Dictionary of Battles''. New York: Stein and Day, 1971. *{{cite book |title=The Oxford Handbook of the State in the Ancient Near East and Mediterranean |editor-first1=Peter Fibiger |editor-last1=Bang |editor-first2=Walter |editor-last2=Scheidel |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2013 |ref=harv}} ==See also== *{{C|Achaemenid Egypt|Achaemenid Egypt topics}} {{Ancient Egypt topics}} {{coord missing|Egypt}} [[Category:6th-century BC conflicts|Pelusium (525 BC)]] [[Category:Battles involving ancient Egypt|Pelusium (525 BC)]] [[Category:Battles involving the Achaemenid Empire|Pelusium (525 BC)]] [[Category:6th century BC in Egypt]] [[Category:525 BC]] [[Category:Naval history of Egypt]] [[Category:Twenty-seventh Dynasty of Egypt]] [[Category:Psychological warfare]] [[Category:Twenty-sixth Dynasty of Egypt]]

{{Infobox military conflict |conflict= Battle of Yarmouk Camp (December 2012) |partof= the [[Syrian Civil War]] and the
[[Rif Dimashq offensive (November 2012–February 2013)]] |image= |caption= |date= 5–17 December 2012
({{Age in months, weeks and days|month1=12|day1=05|year1=2012|month2=12|day2=17|year2=2012}}) |place=[[Yarmouk Camp]], [[Damascus]], [[Syria]] |result= Indecisive * FSA and Liwa al-Asifa take control of most of Yarmouk{{cite web|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/14411|title=Syria: Armed Opposition Takes Yarmouk Refugee Camp|publisher=}} * FSA and Syrian Army agree to leave Yarmouk as a neutral, demilitarized zone, but sporadic clashes continue |combatant1={{flagicon image|Syria-flag 1932-58 1961-63.svg}} [[Free Syrian Army]]
Liwa al-Asifa (Palestinian militia)Jerusalem Post. "The PFLP-GC have accused the Liwa al-Asifa of trying to stir up trouble within the Palestinian refugee community in Yarmouk, while Syrian rebels have accused the PFLP-GC of stifling Palestinian dissent against Assad." [http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?ID=296510&R=R1] |combatant2={{flagicon|Syria}} [[Syria|Ba'athist Syria]] * [[File:Flag of the Syrian Arab Armed Forces.svg|22px]] [[Syrian Armed Forces]] [[File:PFLP-GC Flag.svg|22px]] [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine – General Command|PFLP-GC]]{{cite news|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011101728/https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/nowsyrialatestnews/syria_hits_back_at_un_over_palestinian_refugees_|title=Syria hits back at UN over Palestinian refugees |last=AFP|date=17 December 2012|work=Syria|publisher=NOW.|accessdate=17 December 2012}} |commander1= Unknown |commander2=[[File:PFLP-GC Flag.svg|22px]] [[Ahmed Jibril]] (PFLP-GC leader){{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2012/dec/17/corrections-and-clarifications|title=Corrections and clarifications|date=17 December 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=19 December 2012|location=London}} |units1= Unknown |units2=[[File:Flag of the Syrian Arab Armed Forces.svg|22px]] [[15th Division (Syria)|53rd Army Regiment (Special Forces)]]
[[File:PFLP-GC Flag.svg|22px]] Jihad Jibril Brigade
[[File:PFLP-GC Flag.svg|22px]] Popular Committee-Yarmouk Refugee Camp |casualties1 =Unknown |casualties2 =[[File:PFLP-GC Flag.svg|22px]] 4 killed |casualties3 =23 civilians killed }} {{Campaignbox Syrian Civil War}} {{Campaignbox Rif Dimashq Campaign}} The '''Battle of Yarmouk Camp (December 2012)''' was a period of fierce clashes in Yarmouk Camp during the [[Syrian Civil War]]. [[Yarmouk Camp|Yarmouk]] is a district of [[Damascus]] that is home to the biggest community of [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] refugees in [[Syria]].[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jevFaBhWboO5_Mqrgpk7ycShh4RQ?docId=CNG.493b5bfef777e0c4e6e2103828c1614e.1b1] The fighting was between the [[Syrian Army]] and [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine – General Command|PFLP-GC]] on one side, and [[Syrian opposition|Syrian rebels]] on the other. The rebels included the [[Free Syrian Army]] (FSA) and a group made up of Palestinians, called Liwa al-Asifa or Storm Brigade. On 17 December, it was reported that the FSA and anti-Assad Palestinians had taken control of the camp. The FSA and Syrian Army agreed to leave Yarmouk as a neutral, demilitarized zone, but sporadic clashes continued. ==Background== At the beginning of the Syrian civil war in 2011, the [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine – General Command]] (PFLP-GC) was based in Yarmouk and supported Syria's [[Ba'ath Party (Syrian-dominated faction)|Ba'ath Party]] government led by the [[Al-Assad family]]. At the beginning of the war, tensions arose in Yarmouk between the PFLP-GC and anti-Assad Palestinian residents. On 5 June 2011, a number of Yarmouk residents were [[2011 Israeli border demonstrations|shot dead while protesting at the Israeli border]]. Allegedly angered by the PFLP-GC's refusal to take part in the protests, thousands of mourners burnt-down its headquarters in Yarmouk. PFLP-GC members opened-fire on the crowd, killing 14 Palestinians and wounding 43.[http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=394412 "Report: 14 Palestinians killed in Syria camp"]. [[Ma'an News Agency]], 8 June 2011. Retrieved 26 February 2013.[http://electronicintifada.net/blogs/ali-abunimah/mass-shooting-reported-yarmouk-palestinian-refugee-camp-syria-video "Mass shooting reported in Yarmouk Palestinian refugee camp in Syria - video"]. [[The Electronic Intifada]], 6 June 2011. Retrieved 26 February 2013. On 3 August 2012, [[Al Arabiya]] reported that over 21 civilians were killed when the Syrian Army shelled Yarmouk.[http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/08/03/230127.html "At least 21 killed in shelling on Yarmouk Palestinian refugee camp in Syria: NGO"]. [[Al Arabiya]], 3 August 2012. Palestinian president [[Mahmoud Abbas]] condemned the Syrian Army for shelling the camp and chided the PFLP-GC for dragging Palestinians into the conflict. On 31 October, the FSA announced that they had helped form a brigade made up of anti-Assad Palestinians, called Liwa al-Asifa (Storm Brigade), who have been armed to take control of Yarmouk. The PFLP-GC leader [[Ahmed Jibril]] and his men were accused of harassing Yarmouk's residents and attacking FSA fighters.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.com/topic/syria/rebels-form-brigade-damascus-fight-armed-palestinians-aligned-president-assad|title=Rebels form a brigade in Damascus to fight armed Palestinians aligned with President Assad.|work=Al Jazeera Blogs|accessdate=25 October 2014}} Many Palestinian men from the camp also joined other FSA units and fought with them in the Damascus districts of Tadamon and Al-Hajar Al-Aswad.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2012/Jul-18/181033-palestinians-join-syria-revolt-activists-fsa.ashx#axzz2Aniktc00|title=Palestinians join Syria revolt: activists, FSA|work=The Daily Star Newspaper - Lebanon|accessdate=25 October 2014}} ==December clashes== Fierce fighting in Yarmouk began on 5 December 2012 and lasted until 17 December. The fighting mainly involved the FSA (along with the Liwa al-Asifa brigade) fighting against the PLFP-GC. On 16 December, Syrian Army jets bombed Yarmouk, for the first time since the civil war began. Activists reported that a school and mosque sheltering refugees were hit.{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/16/syria-crisis-camp-idUSL5E8NG4DX20121216 | work=Reuters | title=Syrian fighter jets bomb Palestinian camp in Damascus-activists | date=16 December 2012}} It was reported that at least 23 were killed, all civilians.{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.com/2012/12/16/syrian-planes-hit-yarmouk-mosque-killing-dozens/|title=Syrian planes hit Yarmouk mosque killing dozens|work=euronews|accessdate=25 October 2014}} About 1,000 Palestinians reached Lebanon less than 48 hours after the bombing. The new arrivals said they were now openly hostile towards the Syrian government that had long portrayed itself as the protector of Palestinians in Syria.The Guardian 18 December 2012 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/dec/18/syria-palestinian-refugees-flee-yarmouk Palestinians flee to Lebanon after jet bombs Syria's largest refugee camp] Iran's [[Fars News Agency|Fars News]] said that "terrorist" rebels had entered Yarmouk and shot dead "dozens of Palestinians and Syrian civilians".{{cite web|url=http://english.farsnews.com/newstext.php?nn%3D9107127609 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-12-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121217205317/http://english.farsnews.com/newstext.php?nn=9107127609 |archivedate=2012-12-17 |df= }} On 17 December, it was claimed that many PFLP-GC fighters defected to the rebels. One PFLP-GC commander said "I felt that we became soldiers for the Assad regime, not guards for the camps, so I decided to defect". He claimed that government forces stood by and watched as the PFLP-GC fought the rebels, without helping the Palestinians.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/17/world/middleeast/syrian-airstrike-kills-palestinian-refugees.html|title=A Syrian Airstrike Kills Palestinian Refugees and Costs Assad Support|date=17 December 2012|work=The New York Times}} Ahmed Jibril reportedly fled Damascus for the Mediterranean city of [[Tartous]].[http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/12/16/255444.html]{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/15/us-syria-crisis-palestinians-idUSBRE8BE09O20121215|title=Palestinian faction leader Jibril leaves Damascus: rebels|work=Reuters|accessdate=25 October 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2012/12/16/278330/palestinian-chief-leaves-syrian-capital/|title=PressTV|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121225014929/http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2012/12/16/278330/palestinian-chief-leaves-syrian-capital/|archivedate=25 December 2012|df=dmy-all}} PFLP-GC political bureau member [[Hossam Arafat (Palestinian politician)|Hussam Arafat]], however, announced that Jibril was still in Damascus and that only a small number of fighters had defected. That day, rebel forces gained full control of Yarmouk as well as another Palestinian camp, with help from anti-Assad Palestinians, pushing out the pro-government PFLP-GC fighters.{{cite news|title=WRAPUP 1-Syrian rebels take control of Damascus Palestinian camp|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/17/syria-crisis-idUSL5E8NHGZZ20121217|accessdate=18 December 2012|newspaper=Reuters|date=17 December 2012|first=Mariam|last=Karouny}}{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-20766628 | work=BBC News | title=Syria rebels make further gains | date=18 December 2012}} The pro-government PFLP-GC fighters were reportedly overwhelmed and suffered great losses as they were unable to evacuate their wounded due to rebel snipers on the roofs. Government forces had surrounded the camp, however, as many refugees fled.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/12/2012121717419248502.html|title=Syrian forces surround Palestinian camp|date=17 December 2012|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=18 December 2012}} On 20 December, the FSA said it had pushed all pro-government fighters out of Yarmouk and handed it back to the Palestinians. The day before, fresh fighting on the outskirts of Yarmouk killed a civilian and four PFLP-GC members.[http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/12/20/256099.html] Shortly after, government and rebel representatives agreed that all armed groups should withdraw from Yarmouk and leave it as a neutral zone. The agreement also said that the PFLP-GC should be dismantled and its weapons surrendered. However, a spokesman for the pro-rebel Palestine Refugee Camp Network said, "the implementation of the truce has been problematic" because of "intermittent" government shelling of Yarmouk and clashes on its outskirts.[http://edition.cnn.com/2012/12/20/world/meast/syria-civil-war/index.html "Syrian fight now 'overtly sectarian,' U.N. says"]. [[CNN]], 20 December 2012. An AFP reporter at Batikha, the main entrance to the camp, reported sporadic shooting on 21 December but no gunmen were seen on the streets of Yarmouk.{{fr}}[http://www.lorientlejour.com/category/%C3%80+La+Une/article/793291/%22Nous_rentrons_car_nous_en_avons_assez_detre_humilies%22.html]{{fr}}[http://www.lorientlejour.com/category/Derni%C3%A8res+Infos/article/793297/Nouveaux_combats_entre_pro_et_anti-regime_dans_le_camp_palestinien_de_Yarmouk_a_Damas.html] ==Aftermath== Fellow Palestinian left-wing groups—including the [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine]] (PFLP), the biggest Palestinian leftist group—berated Jibril and the PFLP-GC.[http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2012/al-monitor/pflp-on-defense-in-gaza.html "PFLP on Defense in Gaza Over Ties to Assad"]. [[Al-Monitor]], 27 December 2012. One PFLP official said "Everyone knows the true size of PFLP-GC. They are not representative of the Palestinians". Another said that Jibril "does not even belong to the Palestinian Left. He is closer to the extremist right-wing groups than to revolutionary leftist ones". On 18 December, the [[Palestinian National Council]] (PNC) denounced Jibril, saying it would expel him over his role in the conflict.[http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/14427/ "Ahmad Jibril to be expelled from the PLO"]. ''[[Al Akhbar (Lebanon)]]'', 18 December 2012. On 25 December there was reportedly fighting in or around Yarmouk between rebels and the pro-government [[Jaysh al-Sha'bi]] (or Popular Committees).{{cite web|url=http://www.lorientlejour.com/category/Derni%C3%A8res+Infos/article/793764/Violents_combats_dans_le_camp_palestinien_de_Yarmouk_a_Damas.html|title=Violents combats dans le camp palestinien de Yarmouk à Damas|work=L'Orient-Le Jour|accessdate=25 October 2014}} On 28 December, Iranian [[Press TV]] reported further clashes in Yarmouk.{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2012/12/28/280553/fresh-clashes-erupt-in-yarmouk-camp/ |title=PressTV |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121231140516/http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2012/12/28/280553/fresh-clashes-erupt-in-yarmouk-camp/ |archivedate=31 December 2012 |df= }} The [[UNRWA]] reported that 12 people were killed and 20 wounded during fighting in Yarmouk on 17 January 2013.{{cite web|title=UN: 12 Killed in Fighting in Damascus refugee camp|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2013/Jan-18/202781-un-12-killed-in-fighting-in-damascus-refugee-camp.ashx#axzz2LyiyWg9n|date=18 January 2013|publisher=[[Daily Star (Lebanon)]]}} By January 2014, FSA and Liwa al-Asifa controlled 75% of the refugee camp, while the other 25% was controlled by the Syrian Army and the PFLP-GC.[http://english.al-akhbar.com/content/damascus-yarmouk-starves-relief-convoys-attacked Damascus: Yarmouk Starves as Relief Convoys Attacked] [[Al Akhbar (Lebanon)|Al Akhbar]], 13 January 2014 The situation had become desperate. "The regime forces won't remove the siege on the camp as long as the militants are staying in it" a pro-Assad Palestinian official, Husam Arafat said. Palestinians in the West Bank have been running a campaign to raise awareness of the siege. "History will curse us if you allow Yarmouk's people to die of hunger," one sign read.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/syria-s-civil-war-leaves-at-least-40-dead-at-beseiged-camp-1.2495258|title=Hunger, death in besieged camp near Damascus|publisher=}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Syrian civil war}} {{coord missing|Syria}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yarmouk Camp December 2012}} [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War in 2012]] [[Category:Damascus in the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Damascus Governorate in the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the Syrian government]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the Free Syrian Army]] [[Category:December 2012 events]] [[Category:Battles of the Syrian Civil War]]

{{Infobox musical | name =Beautiful: The Carole King Musical |image =Beautiful Carole King.jpg |image_size = 220px |caption =2014 Broadway Playbill | music = Various Artists | lyrics = Various Artists | book =[[Douglas McGrath]] | orchestrations =[[Steve Sidwell]] | basis =The Songs of [[Carole King]] | premiere_date ={{Start date|df=yes|2013|10|8}} | premiere_location =[[Curran Theatre]], San Francisco | productions =2013 [[San Francisco]]
2014 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]
2015 [[West End theatre|West End]]
2015 U.S. Tour
2017 U.K. Tour
2017 Australian Tour
2017 Tokyo|Japan| awards = }} '''''Beautiful: The Carole King Musical''''' is a [[jukebox musical]] with a book by [[Douglas McGrath]] that tells the story of the early life and career of [[Carole King]], using songs that she wrote, often together with [[Gerry Goffin]], and other contemporary songs by [[Barry Mann]], [[Cynthia Weil]], [[Phil Spector]] and others. The original production of ''Beautiful'' received its world premiere at the [[Curran Theatre]], San Francisco, in October 2013, with direction by Marc Bruni and choreography by [[Josh Prince]], and starring [[Jessie Mueller]] and [[Jake Epstein]] as Carole King and Gerry Goffin. It made its [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut at the [[Stephen Sondheim Theatre]] in January 2014. A [[West End theatre|West End]] production starring [[Katie Brayben]] as Carole began in February 2015. A U.S. tour launched in September 2015. ==Productions== === San Francisco pre-Broadway tryout (2013) === ''Beautiful: The Carole King Musical'' had a pre-Broadway try-out in [[San Francisco]], California, at the [[Curran Theatre]] from September 24, 2013 through October 20, with an official opening October 8. The production was staged by Marc Bruni, with choreography by Josh Prince and musical direction by Jason Howland. [[Jessie Mueller]] played Carole King.Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/181157-Tickets-for-San-Francisco-Engagement-of-Beautiful-The-Carole-King-Musical-on-Sale-Beginning-Aug-16 "Tickets for San Francisco Engagement of 'Beautiful: The Carole King Musical' on Sale Beginning Aug. 16"], playbill.com, August 16, 2013 The musical sold out its entire run at the Curran Theatre.Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/183340-Broadway-Bound-Beautiful-The-Carole-King-Musical-Sells-Out-San-Francisco-Engagement "Broadway-Bound 'Beautiful: The Carole King Musical' Sells Out San Francisco Engagement"], playbill.com, October 17, 2013 === Original Broadway Production (2014) === The musical opened on Broadway at the [[Stephen Sondheim Theatre]] on January 12, 2014, after previews from November 12, 2013. In addition to Mueller as King, the cast features [[Jake Epstein]] as [[Gerry Goffin]], [[Anika Larsen]] as [[Cynthia Weil]] and [[Jarrod Spector]] as [[Barry Mann]].Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/186378-Beautiful-The-Carole-King-Musical-Starring-Jessie-Mueller-as-Music-Icon-Opens-on-Broadway "''Beautiful: The Carole King Musical'', Starring Jessie Mueller as Music Icon, Opens on Broadway"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140113114928/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/186378-Beautiful-The-Carole-King-Musical-Starring-Jessie-Mueller-as-Music-Icon-Opens-on-Broadway |date=2014-01-13 }}, playbill.com, January 12, 2014 King attended the April 3, 2014 performance and appeared on stage with the cast at the curtain call, singing "[[You've Got a Friend]]" together with them.Blank, Matthew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/189664-PHOTO-CALL-Carole-King-Surprises-Cast-of-Broadway-Musical-Beautiful-With-Impromptu-Performance Photo Call: Carole King Surprises Cast of Broadway Musical Beautiful With Impromptu Performance"], playbill.com, April 4, 2014 === Original London Production (2015-2017) === A production in [[London]]'s [[West End theatre|West End]] opened on February 25, 2015, following previews beginning February 10, 2015, at the [[Aldwych Theatre]].{{cite web | url=https://variety.com/2014/legit/news/beautiful-broadway-carole-king-london-west-end-national-tour-1201298183/ | title=Broadway’s Carole King Musical ‘Beautiful’ Expands to London | publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | work=variety.com | date=5 September 2014 | accessdate=30 December 2014}} Prior to the announcement, Baz Bamigboye from the [[Daily Mail]] reported that producers are looking for a full British cast for the transfer, meaning that Jessie Mueller would not transfer for the London production. On September 25, 2014, it was announced that British actress [[Katie Brayben]] would take the lead role of Carole King,{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/beautiful-katie-brayben-carole-king_35883.html | title=Katie Brayben cast as Carole King in Beautiful | publisher=Whats On Stage | work=whatsonstage.com | date=25 September 2014 | accessdate=30 December 2014}} with further casting including [[Alan Morrissey]] as Gerry Goffin, Gary Trainor as [[Don Kirshner]], [[Glynis Barber]] as Genie Klein, [[Lorna Want]] as Cynthia Weil and Ian McIntosh as Barry Mann.{{cite web | url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/full-casting-beautiful-carole-king_36148.html | title=New cast members join Katie Brayben in the upcoming production | publisher=Whats On Stage | work=whatsonstage.com | date=17 October 2014 | accessdate=30 December 2014}} Beginning November 30, 2015, Cassidy Janson took the lead role of Carole King and [[Diane Keen]] replace [[Glynis Barber]] in the role of Genie Klein.{{cite web|url=https://www.londontheatredirect.com/news/1696/Cassidy-Janson---Diane-Keen-join-cast-of-Olivier--Tony---Grammy-Award-winning-Beautiful--The-Carole-King-Musical-.aspx|title=Cassidy Janson & Diane Keen join cast of Olivier, Tony & Grammy Award-winning Beautiful: The Carole King Musical|accessdate=September 12, 2015|date=September 4, 2015|author=Stratford, Tom}} it was announced on May 23, 2017 that the London production would close August 5, 2017. {{cite web|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/beautiful-carole-king-musical-close-west-end_43671.html|title=Beautiful - the Carole King Musical to close in the West End|publisher=}} === U.S. Tour (2015-16) === The musical began a U.S. tour starting in September 2015 in Providence, Rhode Island, at the Providence Performing Arts Center, with engagements across the United States, ending in San Francisco in August 2016.[http://beautifulonbroadway.com/tour/ "Tour"] beautifulonbroadway.com, accessed May 26, 2015 The role of Carole King was played by Abby Mueller (the sister of Jessie Mueller), with Liam Tobin as Gerry Goffin, Ben Fankhauser as Barry Mann and [[Becky Gulsvig]] as Cynthia Weil.Viagas, Robert and Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/full-casting-and-stops-announced-for-national-tour-of-beautiful-the-carole-king-musical-356824# "Full Casting and Stops Announced for National Tour of 'Beautiful— The Carole King Musical' "] playbill.com, August 10, 2015 === UK Tour (2017-18) === A UK tour began September 2017 at the [[Alhambra Theatre, Bradford|Alhambra Theatre]] in [[Bradford]] and ends at the [[New Theatre Oxford|New Theatre]] in [[Oxford]] in May 2018, starring former [[Over_the_Rainbow_(2010_TV_series)|Over the Rainbow]] contestant Bronté Barbé as [[Carole King]]. === Australian Tour (2017-18) === An Australian tour began in Sydney on 24 September 2017 at the [[Sydney Lyric|Lyric Theatre]].{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/australia-melbourne/article/BEAUTIFUL-THE-CAROLE-KING-MUSICAL-To-Open-In-Sydney-In-September-2017-Photos-and-Video-20160511|title=BEAUTIFUL: THE CAROLE KING MUSICAL To Open In Sydney In September 2017. Photos and Video|first=Jade|last=Kops|publisher=}} [[Esther Hannaford]] leads the production, playing Carole King.{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/stage/melbourne-stage/esther-hannaford-to-take-the-lead-in-australian-premiere-of-beautiful-the-carole-king-musical-20170209-gu96f1.html|title=Esther Hannaford to take the lead in Beautiful: The Carole King Musical|first=Debbie|last=Cuthbertson|date=10 February 2017|publisher=|via=The Age}} The musical opened in Melbourne at [[Her Majesty's Theatre, Melbourne|Her Majesty's Theatre]] on 22 February 2018. In Brisbane, performances began at the Lyric Theatre, [[Queensland Performing Arts Centre|QPAC]] on Friday 13 July 2018 running through to Sunday 2nd September 2018. === Second U.S. Tour (2018-) === A second U.S. National tour began September 4, 2018 at the Ellie Caulkins Opera House in Denver, CO. ==Synopsis== ''From the Beautiful: The Carole King Musical cast recording booklet'' ===Act I=== At Carnegie Hall in 1971, Carole King sings "[[So Far Away (Carole King song)|So Far Away]]". Then, in Brooklyn 1958, 16-year-old Carole tells her mother, Genie, she is going into Manhattan to try to sell a song to music publisher [[Don Kirshner|Donnie Kirshner]]. In the long tradition of mothers, Genie is opposed to her daughter's wish and in the equally long tradition of teenagers not caring about their mother's opinion, Carole goes anyway. At [[Brill Building|1650 Broadway]], she hears the "1650 Broadway Medley". She then sings her new song "[[It Might As Well Rain Until September]]". Donnie says he will take it and hopes she has others. At [[Queens_College,_City_University_of_New_York|Queens College]], Carole meets a handsome young lyricist named Gerry Goffin. They agree to collaborate, musically and romantically, which in both cases turns out to be a fertile arrangement. When they go to Donnie's to play their new song, Carole confesses to Gerry that she is pregnant. Gerry asks her to marry him. It gives her an extra depth of feeling when she sings their new song for Donnie, "[[Some Kind of Wonderful (The Drifters song)|Some Kind of Wonderful]]", which [[The Drifters]] then record. They get an office at 1650. While there, Carole meets a new lyricist Cynthia Weil ("[[Happy Days Are Here Again]]"), who is looking for a composer to work with. Gerry and Carole sing their new song "Take Good Care of My Baby", during which Barry Mann, the composer with the office next door, enters. Barry meets Cynthia and they decide to collaborate. As they begin to work, sparks fly. Donnie tells them he needs a song for the Shirelles. The couples compete for the job. In Donnie's office the next morning, Carole and Gerry present "Will You Love Me Tomorrow". Cynthia and Barry perform "He's Sure the Boy I Love". Donnie picks Carole and Gerry's song for [[The Shirelles]] and it goes to no. 1. And so, on either side of the same wall, a competition is born. The two teams turn out an amazing parade of songs: "[[Up on the Roof (song)|Up on the Roof]]", "[[On Broadway (song)|On Broadway]]", "[[The Loco-Motion]]" and "[[You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin']]". Gerry and Carole are at the taping of a TV special where their new song, "[[One Fine Day (song)|One Fine Day]]", is being performed by the dazzling Janelle Woods. During a break, Gerry confesses to Carole that he is restless in their marriage. He wants to sleep with Janelle, and he doesn't want to lie about it. Carole is stunned. As the song begins again, she takes it over and sings it herself. ===Act II=== Carole is in a recording studio doing a demo of "Chains". Gerry is off with Janelle but tells her he will meet her later. Nick, a guitarist, asks Carole to come sing at the Bitter End sometime but she declines — she's a songwriter, not a singer. The thing with Gerry is getting her down so she goes and talks to Cynthia who is also having trouble with Barry — they split up. Carole decides to tell Gerry he has to end the affair with Janelle. As she leaves, Barry comes in. He and Cynthia make up and play their new song, "Walking in the Rain". Gerry shows up, but he is not making sense. He eventually has a breakdown. At the hospital, he tells Carole he will end the affair with Janelle and that he wants to come home. She suggests they make a new start and move to the suburbs ("Pleasant Valley Sunday"). Barry, Cynthia and Donnie come to see the new house. Barry plays their new song, "[[We Gotta Get Out of This Place]]". Depressed that he and Carole can't do as well, Gerry leaves in a funk for the city. While he is gone, it comes out that Barry and Cynthia have seen him with another woman, a singer named Marilyn Wald. Carole goes to Marilyn's apartment and Gerry is there. It's the final straw, and she ends their marriage. At the Bitter End, where Barry and Cynthia hear their song "Uptown", Carole explains she went to Los Angeles for a vacation and has started writing on her own. Nick, the guitarist from the studio who asked her to sing with his group, is playing there and urges her to sing. She sings her new song, "It's Too Late". She decides to move to Los Angeles. At 1650, she says goodbye to Donnie, Barry and Cynthia and plays them a parting present "[[You've Got a Friend]]". In Los Angeles, she records her album, ''Tapestry''. The session goes well until the last song, which she is afraid to sing. It's a song she wrote with Gerry and she is afraid of the feelings it may stir up. Her producer, Lou Adler, persuades her. She sings "(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman". The album is a smash. Carole is at Carnegie Hall for her concert, and is met by Gerry, who apologizes for the way he mistreated her in the past and gives her a final prediction - "you're going all the way". Carole takes to the piano, and performs for her audience. ==Music== ===Musical numbers=== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ;Act 1 *"[[So Far Away (Carole King song)|So Far Away]]" - Carole King *"[[Oh! Carol|Oh Carol]]" - Neil Sedaka† *"1650 Broadway Medley" - Ensemble *"[[It Might as Well Rain Until September]]" - Carole King *"[[Be-Bop-A-Lula]]" - Ensemble† *"[[Some Kind of Wonderful (The Drifters song)|Some Kind of Wonderful]]" - Carole King, Gerry Goffin and [[The Drifters]] *"[[Happy Days Are Here Again]]" - Cynthia Weil *"[[Take Good Care of My Baby]]" - Gerry Goffin and Carole King *"[[Who Put the Bomp (in the Bomp, Bomp, Bomp)|Who Put the Bomp]]" - Barry Mann† *"[[Will You Love Me Tomorrow]]" - Carole King *"[[He's Sure the Boy I Love]]" - Cynthia Weil and Barry Mann *"[[Will You Love Me Tomorrow]]" - [[The Shirelles]] *"[[Up on the Roof (song)|Up on the Roof]]" - Gerry Goffin and The Drifters *"[[On Broadway (song)|On Broadway]]" - The Drifters *"[[The Locomotion]]" - [[Little Eva]] and Ensemble *"[[You've Lost That Lovin' Feeling]]" - Barry Mann and [[The Righteous Brothers]] *"[[One Fine Day (song)|One Fine Day]]" - Janelle, Backup Singers and Carole King {{col-break}} ;Act 2 *"[[Chains (Cookies song)|Chains]]" - Carole King and Ensemble *"[[Walking in the Rain (The Ronettes song)|Walking in the Rain]]" - Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil *"[[Pleasant Valley Sunday]]" - Marilyn Wald, Gerry Goffin and Ensemble *"[[We Gotta Get Out of This Place]]" - Barry Mann *"Will You Love Me Tomorrow" (Reprise) - Carole King† *"[[Uptown (The Crystals song)|Uptown]]" - "Uptown" Singer and Ensemble *"[[It's Too Late (Carole King song)|It's Too Late]]" - Carole King and Ensemble *"[[You've Got a Friend]]" - Carole King, Barry Mann, Cynthia Weil and Don Kirshner *"[[(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman]]" - Carole King and Ensemble *"[[Beautiful (Carole King song)|Beautiful]]" - Carole King and Company *"[[I Feel the Earth Move]]" - Carole King and Company {{col-end}} ''† Not included on the original Broadway Cast Album.'' ===Orchestra=== The musical uses a 12-member orchestra consisting of three keyboards, two guitars, bass, drums, percussion, two reeds, trumpet/flugelhorn, and trombone/bass trombone.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=495178 | title=Beautiful The Carole King Musical Opening Night Credits | publisher=[[Internet Broadway Database]] | work=ibdb.com | accessdate=30 December 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.playbillvault.com/Show/Detail/Whos_who/14036/53371/Beautiful-The-Carole-King-Musical |title=Inside the Playbill: Beautiful: The Carole King Musical Playbill Opening Night at Stephen Sondheim Theatre |publisher=[[Playbill Vault]] |work=playbillvault.com |accessdate=30 December 2014 |pages=4 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141111042623/http://www.playbillvault.com/Show/Detail/Whos_who/14036/53371/Beautiful-The-Carole-King-Musical |archivedate=11 November 2014 |df= }} In addition the performer playing [[Carole King]] plays the piano if it is Katie Brayben (London) whereas Jessie Mueller (Broadway) needed piano lessons so she could mime.{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/jessie-mueller-to-star-in-beautiful-the-carole-king-musical-arriving-on-bro-208447 | title=Jessie Mueller to Star in Beautiful: The Carole King Musical, Arriving on Broadway in November | publisher=[[Playbill]] | work=playbill.com | date=12 August 2013 | accessdate=30 December 2014}} ===Recordings=== The Broadway cast album was recorded in February 2014 by [[Ghostlight Records]] and was released in digital form on April 1, 2014. It was in stores as of May 13, 2014. (The Broadway cast album includes the song "You've Got a Friend", although that song is not listed in the opening night playbill.) The album was also released on a vinyl format.Gioia, Michael and Hetrick, Adam.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/187619-Ghostlight-Records-Will-Record-Broadways-Beautiful-The-Carole-King-Musical Ghostlight Records Will Record Broadway's Beautiful: The Carole King Musical"] Playbill.com, February 13, 2014Hetrick, Adam.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/191052-Cast-Album-of-Beautiful-The-Carole-King-Musical-Hits-Stores-May-13 "Cast Album of 'Beautiful: The Carole King Musical' Hits Stores May 13"] Playbill.com, May 13, 2014 ==Principal roles and original casts== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Character ! Broadway Cast ! West End Cast{{cite web | url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/complete-casting-announced-for-west-ends-beautiful-the-carole-king-musical-333464 | title=Complete Casting Announced for West End's Beautiful: The Carole King Musical | publisher=[[Playbill]] | work=playbill.com | date=17 October 2014 | accessdate=30 December 2014}} ! U.S. Tour Cast ! Japan Cast ! U.K. Tour Cast ! Australian Tour Cast |- ! scope="row" |[[Carole King]] |[[Jessie Mueller]] |[[Katie Brayben]] | Abby Mueller | Nana Mizuki
Ayaka Hirahara | Bronté Barbé |[[Esther Hannaford]] |- ! scope="row" |[[Gerry Goffin]] |[[Jake Epstein]] |[[Alan Morrissey]] | Liam Tobin | Kanata Irei | Kane Oliver Parry |Josh Piterman |- ! scope="row" |[[Cynthia Weil]] | [[Anika Larsen]] | [[Lorna Want]] | [[Becky Gulsvig]] | Sonim | Amy Ellen Richardson |[[Amy Lehpamer]] |- ! scope="row" |[[Barry Mann]] | [[Jarrod Spector]] | Ian McIntosh | Ben Fankhauser | Akinori Nakagawa | Matthew Gonsalves |Mat Verevis |- ! scope="row" |[[Don Kirshner]] | Jeb Brown | Gary Trainor | Curt Bouril | Shinji Takeda | [[Adam Howden]] |Mike McLeish |- ! scope="row" |Genie Klein | [[Liz Larsen]] | [[Glynis Barber]] | Suzanne Grodner | Miyuki Tsurugi | [[Carol_Royle|Carol Royle]] |Anne Wood |- ! scope="row" |Betty | Rebecca LaChance | Joanna Woodward | Sarah Bockel | Ayaka Larrison | Leigh Lothian |Stefanie Caccamo |- ! scope="row" |[[Neil Sedaka]]/[[Bobby Hatfield|Righteous Brother]]/[[Lou Adler]] | Kevin Duda | Ed Currie | John Michael Dias | Gen Yamada | Ben Morris |Jason Arrow |- ! scope="row" |Lucille/[[The Shirelles|Shirelle]]/"One Fine Day" Backup Singer | Carly Hughes | Danielle Steers | Salisha Thomas | Natsuko Takagi | Paige Miller |Ruva Ngwenya |- ! scope="row" | [[The Drifters]] | E. Clayton Cornelious, Douglas Lyons, Arbender J. Robinson, James Harkness | | | | Matthew Elliot Campbell, Khalid Daley, Matt Mills, Simeon Montague | |- ! scope="row" |[[The Shirelles|Shirelle]]/Janelle Woods | Rashidra Scott | Tanisha L. Spring | Rebecca E. Covington | Eliana | Jessica Joslin |Akina Edmonds |- ! scope="row" |[[The Shirelles| Shirelle]]/[[Little Eva]]/"One Fine Day" Backup Singer | Ashley Blanchet | Lucy St. Louis | Ashley Blanchet | MARIA-E | Esme Laudat |Chloé Zuel |- ! scope="row" |[[The Shirelles|Shirelle]]/"One Fine Day" Backup Singer/"Uptown" Singer | Alysha Deslorieux | Tanya Nicole-Edwards | Britney Coleman | Marie Sugaya | Paige Miller |Rebecca Selley |- ! scope="row" |[[Bill Medley|Righteous Brother]]/Nick | Josh Davis | Dylan Turner | Andrew Brewer | Yasuhiro Yamano | Grant McConvey |Andrew Cook |- ! scope="row" |Marilyn Wald | Sara King | Vivien Carter | DeLaney Westfall | Sayaka Watabiki | Emma Lucia |[[Naomi Price]] |} ===Notable cast replacements=== * [[Melissa Benoist]] played the role of Carole King from June 7, 2018 until August 4, 2018. * Abby Mueller replaced Melissa Benoist in the role of Carole King on August 7, 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/abby-mueller-returns-to-broadway-cast-of-beautifulthe-carole-king-musical-august-7|title=Abby Mueller Returns to Broadway Cast of Beautiful—The Carole King Musical August 7|last=Gans|first=Andrew|work=[[Playbill]]|accessdate=October 29, 2018}} * [[Diane Keen]] replaced Glynis Barber in the role of Genie Klein on the West End on November 30, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/westend/article/Cassidy-Janson-To-Play-Carole-King-In-BEAUTIFUL-From-Nov-2015-20150904|title=Official: Cassidy Janson to Play Carole King in BEAUTIFUL from Nov 2015!|author=BWW News Desk|date=4 September 2015|work=BroadwayWorld.com}} * [[Jessica Keenan Wynn]] played Cynthia Weil until July 8, 2018. * [[Kara Lindsay]] returned to play Cynthia Weil on July 10, 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/kara-lindsay-will-return-to-broadways-beautiful|title=Kara Lindsay Returns to Broadway’s Beautiful July 12|last=McPhee|first=Ryan|work=[[Playbill]]|accessdate=October 29, 2018}} * [[Kate Reinders]] replaced Kara Lindsay in the role of Cynthia Weil on October 19, 2018. ==Critical reception== [[Ben Brantley]], reviewing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', called the musical a "friendly, formulaic bio-musical". He wrote that the musical shows the change in King from a modest songwriter to the popular and confident performer of those songs, showing the "real, conflicted person within the reluctant star."Brantley, Ben. [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/13/theater/beautiful-the-carole-king-musical-at-sondheim-theater.html?_r=0# "Theater Review. 'Beautiful: The Carole King Musical' at Sondheim Theater"], ''The New York Times'', January 13, 2014 Jesse Green, in his review for the ''[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]'', praised the performers but criticized the book, writing that the musical does not have the "dramatic coherence of book biomusicals".Green, Jesse. [http://www.vulture.com/2014/01/theater-review-beautiful-carole-king.html "Theater Review: A Natural Woman and Not Much Else in ''Beautiful: The Carole King Musical''"], vulture.com, January 13, 2014 Similarly, Elyse Sommer, in her review for ''curtainup.com'', praised the performers, especially Mueller, Spector and Larsen, as well as the "shimmery lighting" and the costumes. She wrote that while the musical "doesn't hang its songs on the greatest or most suspenseful story ever told, it has enough bounce and Broadway show glitz to keep you in your seat".Sommer, Elyse. [http://www.curtainup.com/beautifulcaroleking.html "A CurtainUp Review. ''Beautiful – The Carole King Musical''"], curtainup.com, January 8, 2014 ==Awards and nominations== ===Original Broadway production=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%;" |- ! style="width:5%;"| Year ! style="width:20%;"| Award ! style="width:45%;"| Category ! style="width:20%;"| Nominee ! style="width:10%;"| Result |- | rowspan=13 style="text-align:center;"| 2014 | rowspan=7| [[Tony Award]] | colspan=2| [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Book of a Musical|Best Book of a Musical]] | [[Douglas McGrath]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Leading Actress in a Musical|Best Leading Actress in a Musical]] | [[Jessie Mueller]] | {{won}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Featured Actor in a Musical|Best Featured Actor in a Musical]] | [[Jarrod Spector]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Musical|Best Featured Actress in a Musical]] | [[Anika Larsen]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Orchestrations|Best Orchestrations]] | Steve Sidwell | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award for Best Sound Design|Best Sound Design]] | Brian Ronan | {{won}} |- | rowspan=6| [[Drama Desk Award]] | colspan=2| [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Musical|Outstanding Musical]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Book of a Musical|Outstanding Book of a Musical]] | Douglas McGrath | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actress in a Musical|Outstanding Actress in a Musical]] | Jessie Mueller | {{won}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Featured Actress in a Musical|Outstanding Featured Actress in a Musical]] | Anika Larsen | {{won}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Orchestrations|Outstanding Orchestrations]] | Steve Sidwell | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Sound Design in a Musical|Outstanding Sound Design in a Musical]] | Brian Ronan | {{won}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2015 | [[Grammy Award]] | [[Grammy Award for Best Musical Theater Album|Best Musical Theater Album]] | Jessie Mueller (principal soloist); Jason Howland, Steve Sidwell & [[Billy Jay Stein]] (producers) | {{won}} |} ===Original London production=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%;" |- ! style="width:5%;"| Year ! style="width:20%;"| Award Ceremony ! style="width:45%;"| Category ! style="width:20%;"| Nominee ! style="width:10%;"| Result |- | rowspan="8" style="text-align:center;"| 2015 | rowspan="8"| [[Laurence Olivier Award]] | colspan="2"| [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best New Musical|Best New Musical]] | {{nominated}} |- | [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actress in a Musical|Best Actress in a Musical]] | Katie Brayben | {{won}} |- | [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role in a Musical|Best Actor in a Supporting Role in a Musical]] | Ian McIntosh | {{nominated}} |- | [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role in a Musical|Best Actress in a Supporting Role in a Musical]] | [[Lorna Want]] | {{won}} |- | [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Theatre Choreographer|Best Theatre Choreographer]] | Josh Prince | {{nominated}} |- | [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Costume Design|Best Costume Design]] | Alejo Vietti | {{nominated}} |- | [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Sound Design|Best Sound Design]] | Brian Ronan | {{nominated}} |- | [[Laurence Olivier Award for Outstanding Achievement in Music|Outstanding Achievement in Music]] | The Orchestra | {{nominated}} |} == Film adaptation == On March 22, 2015, it was announced that [[Sony Pictures]] would be bringing the musical to the big screen with Douglas McGrath adapting his book into a screenplay and stage producer Paul Blake producing through [[Tom Hanks]] and [[Gary Goetzman]]'s production company, [[Playtone]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/beautiful-the-carole-king-musical-movie-sony-tom-hanks-1201457689/|title=Sony to Make ‘Beautiful: The Carole King Musical’ a Feature Film|first=Brent|last=Lang|date=22 March 2015|website=variety.com|accessdate=18 April 2018}} == Producers == The producers of the original Broadway production include: Paul Blake, [[Sony/ATV Music Publishing]], Jeffery A. Sine, Richard A. Smith, Mike Bosner, Harriet Newman Leve, Elaine Krauss, Terry Schnuck, Orin Wolf, Patty Baker, Roger Faxon, Larry Magrid, Kit Seidel, Lawrence S. Toppall, Fakston Productions, Mary Soloman, William C. Cohen, John Gore, Barbara Freitag, Loraine Alterman Boyle, Matthew C. Blank, Tim Hogue, Joel Hyatt, Marianne Mills, [[Michael J. Moritz Jr.]], StylesFour Production, Corey Brunish, Brisa Trinchero, Jeremiah J. Harris, Sherry Kondor (Executive Producer), Christine Russell (Executive Producer).{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/personlistpage/person-list|title=Person List|website=Playbill|access-date=2016-06-24}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.beautifulonbroadway.com/ Official Broadway Site] * [http://beautifulinlondon.co.uk/ Official West End Site] * {{ibdb show|495177|Beautiful: The Carole King Musical}} {{Carole King}} [[Category:2013 musicals]] [[Category:Broadway musicals]] [[Category:Rock musicals]] [[Category:Carole King]] [[Category:Musicals inspired by real-life events]] [[Category:Works by Douglas McGrath]] [[Category:Jukebox musicals]]

revision.comment: /* Media coverage */ Corrected references to FSB as “KGB” and removed a POV characterization.
revision.text:
'''Brendan Kyle Hatcher''' is a United States [[diplomat]] who was called "the most closely surveilled American in Russia" by ABC News Investigative Reporter Brian Ross in a September 2009 investigative report. Hatcher gained notoriety in August 2009 after the Russian tabloid ''[[Komsomolskaya Pravda]]'', a newspaper which Russian intelligence expert [[Andrei Soldatov]] ties to the [[Federal Security Services]] (FSB) of the [[Russian Federation]], showed a video <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/andrei-soldatov-irina-borogan/project-id-who%E2%80%99s-bugging-russian-opposition |title=Project_ID: Who’s bugging the Russian opposition? |website=Opendemocracy.net |date=2012-02-24 |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref> of him while accusing him of being an undercover [[CIA]] agent in Russia.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jill Dougherty |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/US/09/24/russia.us.sextape/index.html |title=U.S. calls purported sex tape 'doctored' and 'smear campaign' |website=Edition.cnn.com |date=2009-09-24 |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref> The media reports were quickly condemned by investigating authorities in the U.S. as fabricated.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/09/23/complains-russia-sex-tape-smear.html U.S. Complains to Russia About Sex Tape 'Smear'] foxnews.com 2009/09/23</ref>
==Media coverage== According to Eli Lake of ''[[The Washington Times]]'', Hatcher became one of several American diplomats and journalists to be attacked and falsely accused between 2007 and 2011 after the [[Obama Administration]]'s "reset" with Russia.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/aug/4/russia-uses-dirty-tricks-despite-us-reset/ |title=Russia uses dirty tricks despite U.S. 'reset' |newspaper=[[The Washington Times]] |date= |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref> Hatcher served as Political Officer who worked to promote [[human rights]] and [[freedom of religion]] in Russia from 2008 to 2010. He was awarded in June 2010 by the [[State Department]] for his "courage and character, commitment to excellence, and support of human rights and religious freedom in spite of exceedingly difficult circumstances and personal hardship." As part of his job, Hatcher would meet with opposition figures, government officials, NGOs, journalists, and religious leaders to promote human rights and religious equality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.st-catherine.ru/index.php?lang%3Deng%26sitepartid%3D9%26id%3D1161%26level%3D0 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326121900/http://old.st-catherine.ru/index.php?lang=eng&sitepartid=9&id=1161&level=0 |archivedate=2012-03-26 |df= }}</ref> Hatcher was fully exonerated by the media and State Department, and he was lauded by his colleagues for heroism.<ref>{{cite web|last=Beam |first=Christopher |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2277407/ |title=Honey traps: Do spies use sex to extract secrets? |website=Slate.com |date=2010-12-09 |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref>
On August 6, 2009, Russian media sources with links to the FSB (the successor organization to the [[KGB]] of the [[Soviet Union]]) released real video images and pictures of Hatcher that had been spliced with images of another person.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2009/09/24/idINIndia-42678820090924 |title=U.S. complains to Russia over sex tape 'smear' |website=In.reuters.com |date=2009-09-24 |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref> The doctored images emerged just one month after the first presidential summit between U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] and Russian President Dmitry Medvedev which prominently featured discussions on human rights and corruption.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/07/06/AR2009070603623.html |title=Obama Endorses Medvedev's Agenda but Pushes for More Democratic Reforms |website=Washingtonpost.com |date=2009-07-07 |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref> The Ambassador of the [[Embassy of the United States in Moscow]], [[John Beyrle]], issued a formal protest to the [[Russian government]], stating that the Russian media reports about Hatcher were completely untrue and had no place in the development of better relations between the two superpowers. Despite Beyrle's protest, neither Hatcher nor the U.S government received an apology from Russian officials for the "smear campaign."<ref name="abcnews1">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/russian-sex-tape-smear-american-diplomat/story?id=8651311 |title=Russian Sex Tape Used to Smear American Diplomat - ABC News |website=Abcnews.go.com |date=2009-09-23 |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref>
On September 23, 2009, [[ABC News]] ran an investigative piece on ''[[Nightline]]'' concerning the "smear campaign" against Hatcher, including the interview with Ambassador Beyrle. During the interview, Beyrle stated that Hatcher was 100% innocent of any wrongdoing. Beyrle had previously awarded Hatcher in May 2009 for his success in promoting freedom of religion and human rights in Russia, and commented that an element in Russia had attacked Hatcher to discredit him and his work as well as prevent the two countries from developing closer ties. Soldatov further noted that only Russian intelligence agents would be interested in smearing Hatcher to force his dismissal from Russia.
In the course of the segment, retired FBI Counterintelligence Officer and Russian intelligence services expert David Majors pointed out that the video segments had been doctored to smear Hatcher and to reduce his effectiveness at his job. Major pointed out obvious flaws in the video sequence and assessed that the false media reports were a "dirty trick," constituting a failed attempt to frame Hatcher and ruin his reputation as a change agent in the human rights activist community.<ref name="abcnews1"/>
On September 24, 2009, State Department spokesperson Ian Kelly called Hatcher "one of our best" diplomats, and confirmed that Hatcher had been smeared with false media reports to discredit his work promoting human rights and religious freedom.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.state.gov/md129583.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706073213/http://m.state.gov/md129583.htm |archivedate=2011-07-06 |df= }} </ref> Kelly noted that the State Department deplored this type of activity by the Russians at a time when diplomats like Hatcher were working to improve bilateral relations.
In the February 19, 2017, episode of HBO series [[Last Week Tonight]], host John Oliver called the FSB fake tape "ridiculous" as part of his larger commentary on the lengths to which the Kremlin will go to discredit its opponents.
Prior to his service in the diplomatic corps, Hatcher served as an intelligence analyst with the [http://www.treasury.gov/about/organizational-structure/offices/Pages/Office-of-Intelligence-Analysis.aspx Department of the Treasury, Office of Intelligence and Analysis], where he focused on fighting the sources of [[terrorism financing]]. In the summer of 2004, Hatcher conducted research for the Center for East Asian Studies in Vladivostok, Russia, where he focused on Russian attitudes towards Chinese migrants. He later presented and published a paper detailing his findings, which included a scathing commentary about Russian racism and xenophobia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.froginawell.net/china/category/china-russia/ |title=China-Russia – Frog in a Well China |website=Froginawell.net |date= |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref> Prior to his research in Russia, Hatcher worked in the private sector as a business manager, and he served in the Peace Corps as a volunteer in Kazakhstan (part of the former Soviet Union) where he taught economics at the Taraz Polytechnical College in [[Taraz|Taraz, Kazakhstan]]. Former Soviet officials have long been skeptical of the Peace Corps as a cover for US spies, evidenced by Russia’s decision to kick out the Peace Corps in 2002.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2002-12-28/world/peace.corps_1_peace-corps-situation-in-russian-regions-social-tasks?_s%3DPM%3AWORLD |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101021064828/http://articles.cnn.com/2002-12-28/world/peace.corps_1_peace-corps-situation-in-russian-regions-social-tasks?_s=PM%3AWORLD |archivedate=2010-10-21 |df= }}</ref>
==Personal background and honors== Hatcher hails from Nashville, Tennessee and attended [[Montgomery Bell Academy]], famous as the source for the blockbuster film [[Dead Poets Society]]. In 1997, Hatcher graduated from the [[University of Georgia]], which honored him as one of its top 40 under 40 graduates in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alumni.uga.edu/alumni/index.php/site/blog/25387 |title=Blog - UGA Alumni Association |website=Alumni.uga.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref> In 2005, Hatcher received his masters from the [[Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey]] (MIIS), where he delivered the student commencement address alongside Russian scientist Roald Sagdeev and philanthropist Susan Eisenhower.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cns.miis.edu/alumni/photos_graduation_2005.htm |title=CNS Alumni Photos: 2005 | James Martin Center for Nonproliferation Studies |website=Cns.miis.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref> The U.S. Government honored him as a Presidential Management Fellow in 2005.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hatcher, Brendan Kyle}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American diplomats]] [[Category:Diplomatic incidents]] [[Category:Middlebury College alumni]]

revision.text:
'''Bullying in the legal profession''' is believed to be more common than in some other professions. It is believed that its adversarial, hierarchical tradition contributes towards this.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.unswlawjournal.unsw.edu.au/sites/default/files/t1_le_mire_and_owens.pdf# |title=Le Mire, Suzanne; Owens, Rosemary ''A propitious moment?: Workplace bullying and regulation of the legal profession'' University of New South Wales Law Journal, The Volume 37 Issue 3 (Dec 2014) |access-date=2015-01-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150201001112/http://www.unswlawjournal.unsw.edu.au/sites/default/files/t1_le_mire_and_owens.pdf# |archive-date=2015-02-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Women, trainees and solicitors who have been qualified for five years or less are more impacted, as are ethnic minority lawyers and lesbian, gay and bisexual lawyers.<ref>[http://www.journalonline.co.uk/News/1009923.aspx#.VMfxpyzp-24 Society publishes guidance on tackling bullying in solicitor profession] The Journal of the Law Society of Scotland 27 June 2011</ref>
Half of women lawyers and one in three men who took part in a study by the [[Law Council of Australia]] (LCA) reported they had been [[bullied]] or [[intimidated]] in the [[workplace]].<ref>Leanne Mezrani 4 February 2014 [http://www.lawyersweekly.com.au/news/15078-Bullying-rates-alarming Bullying rates 'alarming'] Lawyers Weekly</ref> The Law Council of Australia has found that women face significant levels of [[discrimination]], with one of the study's key figures telling Lawyers Weekly the profession is a "men's only club".<ref>Leanne Mezrani 14 March 2014 [http://www.lawyersweekly.com.au/news/15197-Law-is-failing-and-hurting-women Law is failing and hurting women] Lawyers Weekly</ref>
According to former High Court judge Michael Kirby, the rudeness of judges trickles down to senior lawyers who then vent their frustrations on more junior staff, thus creating a cycle of bullying and [[Occupational stress|stress]] that is rife within the [[legal profession]].<ref name=judge>[http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/bullying-judges-breed-stressful-system-kirby-20130221-2eudp.html Bullying judges breed stressful system: Kirby]</ref>
==See also== * [[Legal abuse]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Omari, M. & Paull, M. (2014). “Shut up and bill”: Workplace bullying challenges for the legal profession. International Journal of the Legal Profession. Volume 20, Issue 2, 2013 p1-20.
== External links == * [http://www.bullyonline.org/cases/case50.htm Bullying in the UK legal profession Case history #50] * [http://www.bullyonline.org/cases/case52.htm Bullying in the UK legal profession Case history #52] * James Barnes 16 October 2012 The Global Legal Post [http://www.globallegalpost.com/global-view/bullying-rife-in-english-legal-profession-52164738 Bullying rife in English legal profession] * Sophie Schroder 8 Oct 2014 Australasian Lawyer [http://www.australasianlawyer.com.au/news/lawyers-some-of-australias-worst-bullies-192671.aspx Lawyers some of Australia’s worst bullies?] * The Connecticut Law Tribune August 27, 2014 [http://www.ctlawtribune.com/id=1202668248833/Editorial-Confronting-Bullying-Within-the-Legal-Profession?slreturn=20150027093317 Editorial: Confronting Bullying Within the Legal Profession] * [http://www.thestrongfirm.com/2014/11/17/knocking-out-bullying-in-the-legal-profession/ Knocking Out Bullying in the Legal Profession] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K9QXWhowQUA Civility Matters: Rudeness and Bullying in the Legal Profession] * 8 January 2014 Legal Futures [http://www.legalfutures.co.uk/latest-news/bullying-work-rise-says-lawyer-support-charity Bullying at work on the rise, says lawyer support charity] * David Yamada December 10, 2013 [https://newworkplace.wordpress.com/2013/12/10/bullying-lawyer-suspended-from-practice-for-two-years Bullying lawyer suspended from practice for two years] * Harriet Alexander March 23, 2013 [http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/dpp-warns-lawyers-stop-bullying-one-another-or-else-20130322-2glam.html DPP warns lawyers: stop bullying one another or else] * [http://www.psycholawlogy.com/2014/02/06/bullying-work-legal-organizations-coping-strategies-health-problems Bullying at Work Legal Organizations, Coping Strategies, and Health Problems] * [http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/lawyer-says-firms-harassment-made-her-ill-20100302-pgfj.html Lawyer says firm's harassment made her ill] March 3, 2010 Ben Schneiders
{{Bullying}} {{Law}}

[[File:Chatham House over the Jubilee weekend (7345325368).jpg|thumb|[[Chatham House]]]] The '''Chatham House Rule''' is a system for holding debates and discussion panels on controversial issues, named after the headquarters of the UK [[Royal Institute of International Affairs]], based in Chatham House, London, where the rule originated in June 1927.
At a meeting held under the Chatham House Rule, anyone who comes to the meeting is free to use information from the discussion, but is not allowed to reveal who made any comment. It is designed to increase openness of discussion.
==The rule== The rule was created in 1927 and refined in 1992. Since its most recent refinement in 2002, the rule states:<ref name=rule>{{cite web| work = About | url = http://www.chathamhouse.org/about/chatham-house-rule/ |title=Chatham House Rule |publisher=Chatham House | location = [[United Kingdom|UK]] |accessdate=2014-07-14}}</ref> {{quote|When a meeting, or part thereof, is held under the Chatham House Rule, participants are free to use the [[information]] received, but neither the identity nor the affiliation of the speaker(s), nor that of any other participant, may be revealed.}} Sometimes the reference is made to ''Chatham House rules''.<ref name=MW01/> However, Chatham House states that the singular should be used as there is only one rule.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chathamhouse.org/about/chatham-house-rule|website=Chatham House Rule|title=Chatham House|publisher=Chatham House|accessdate=3 August 2016}}</ref>
==Purpose== The rule is designed to increase openness of discussion of [[public policy]] and current affairs, as it allows people to express and discuss controversial opinions and arguments without suffering the risk of stalling their career or even dismissal from their job, and with a clear separation from the opinion and the view of their employer.
The rule allows people to speak as individuals and to express views that may not be those of their organisations, and therefore encourages free discussion. Speakers are free to voice their own opinions, and to contest the opinions of other participants, without concern for their personal reputation or their official duties and affiliations. The Chatham House Rule resolves a boundary problem faced by many [[community of practice|communities of practice]], in that it permits acknowledgement of the community or conversation, while protecting the freedom of interaction that is necessary for the community to carry out its conversations. It is designed to reduce the risk of what has come to be described as [[groupthink]], where unpopular views are excluded from discussion, reducing the range of opinions an organisation can discuss.
The aim of the rule is to guarantee anonymity to those speaking within its walls so that better [[international relations]] may be achieved. The rule is now used internationally as an aid to free discussion.<ref>{{Cite web | location = [[Finland]] | author-link = Jukka Rislakki | first = Jukka | last = Rislakki | title = Informaatiouhat mietityttävät sekä virolaisia että suomalaisia | publisher = [[Suomen Kuvalehti]] | date = February 24, 2011 | language = Finnish | url = http://suomenkuvalehti.fi/blogit/eri-mielta/verkossa-sk82011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110227111229/http://suomenkuvalehti.fi/blogit/eri-mielta/verkossa-sk82011 | archivedate = February 27, 2011 | df = }}</ref> The original rule of 1927 was refined in October 1992 and again in 2002.<ref name=rule /> Chatham House has translated the rule into [[Arabic]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Russian language|Russian]].<ref>{{Citation | publisher = Chatham House | url = http://www.chathamhouse.org/about/chatham-house-rule/chatham-house-rule-translations | work = About us | title = Chatham House Rule Translations}}.</ref>
The rule is a contrast (or a compromise) between private meetings, where revealing what was said in the meeting is forbidden, and ''[[Journalism sourcing#"On the record"|on the record]]'' events where the discussion is completely public and attributed.
Generally, the Chatham House Rule is imposed as a condition of being allowed to attend a meeting or event: all participants are understood to have agreed that it would be conducive to free discussion that they should be subject to the rule for the relevant part of the meeting. The success of the rule may depend upon it being considered morally binding, particularly in circumstances where a failure to comply with the rule may not result in sanction.
==Concern over ECB use== In May 2015, the release of a rule-bound speech by [[European Central Bank]] board member [[Benoît Cœuré]] triggered broader attention to the bank's use of the system. The [[Benoît Cœuré#European Central Bank|Cœuré speech]] influenced currency, stock and bond markets.<ref name="FT_2015-05-20">{{Cite news | title = Benoît Cœuré speech highlights central bank links to financiers - FT.com | last = Jones | first = Claire | last2 = Fleming | first2 = Sam | website = [[Financial Times]] | date = 20 May 2015 | accessdate = 2016-02-11 | url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f48123e2-ff02-11e4-8dd4-00144feabdc0.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150707225427/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/f48123e2-ff02-11e4-8dd4-00144feabdc0.html | archive-date = 2015-07-07 }}</ref><ref name="Bloomberg_2015-05-19">{{Cite news | title = Hedge Fund Diners Get ECB’s Market-Moving News Hours Early | last = Black | first = Jeff | last2 = Worrachate | first2 = Anchalee | website = [[Bloomberg Businessweek]] | date = 19 May 2015 | accessdate = 2016-02-11 | url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-05-19/ecb-serves-hedge-fund-diners-qe-treat-most-investors-didn-t-know | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150816075211/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-05-19/ecb-serves-hedge-fund-diners-qe-treat-most-investors-didn-t-know | archive-date = 2015-08-16 | dead-url = no }}</ref><ref name="Telegraph_2015-05-28">{{Cite news | title = ECB told off by ombudsman for fumbling market moving speech | last = Spence | first = Peter | newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 28 May 2015 | accessdate = 2016-02-11 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/economics/11636422/ECB-told-off-by-ombudsman-for-fumbling-market-moving-speech.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151201130922/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/economics/11636422/ECB-told-off-by-ombudsman-for-fumbling-market-moving-speech.html | archive-date = 2015-12-01 | dead-url = no }}</ref> In the aftermath, other recent ECB invocations of the rule regarding a question-and-answer session and opening remarks for Cœuré, respectively, by ECB Vice President [[Vitor Constancio]] and another member of the board, [[Peter Praet]], also gained attention. An [[Governing Council of the European Central Bank|ECB governing council]] member Boštjan Jazbec of [[Slovenia]] also had, the same month, held a question-and-answer session under the rule.<ref name=MW01>Fletcher, Laurence, [http://www.marketwatch.com/story/ecb-error-spurs-questions-about-policy-disclosures-2015-05-25-17485932 "ECB error spurs questions about policy disclosures"], ''[[MarketWatch]]'', May 25, 2015. Retrieved 2015-05-26.</ref>
== See also == * [[Source (journalism)|Journalism sourcing]] * [[Whistleblower]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite web |url = http://www.chathamhouse.org/about/chatham-house-rule |publisher = Chatham House | location=UK | title = Chatham House Rule |accessdate=2014-06-11 }} With explanation and link to translations in different languages.
[[Category:Classified information]] [[Category:International relations]] [[Category:Meetings]] [[Category:Chatham House| ]] [[Category:1927 introductions]]
