| start_date = | stop_date = | est_completion = | topped_out_date = | completion_date = 1971 | opened_date = {{start_date|1971}} | destruction_date = {{end_date|1986|03|15}} | cost = | ren_cost = | client = [[Industrial and Commercial Bank Limited]]
Hotel New World | owner = Ng Khong Lim | landlord = | affiliation = Lian Yak Realty | height = | architectural = | tip = | floor_count = 6 | architect = | architecture_firm = | engineer = | structural_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | main_contractor = | rooms = | parking = | website = | embed = yes | embedded = | references = | footnotes = | hotel_chain = | number_of_rooms = 67 | number_of_suites = | number_of_restaurants = 1 | number_of_bars = | facilities = }} }} The '''collapse of the Hotel New World''' ({{Lang-zh|s=新世界酒店倒塌事件}}; {{Lang-ms|Runtuhnya Hotel New World}}; {{Lang-ta|நியூ வர்ல்டு சம்பவம்}}) occurred on 15 March 1986, and was Singapore's deadliest civil disaster since the [[Spyros disaster]] on 12 October 1978.{{cite techreport|author1=Allen Yu-Hung LAI|author2=Seck L. TAN|date=August 2013|title=Impact of Disasters and Disaster Risk Management in Singapore: A Case Study of Singapore’s Experience in Fighting the SARS Epidemic|series=ERIA Discussion Paper Series|at=Table 1|id=ERIA-DP-2013-14|institution=Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA)|url=http://www.eria.org/ERIA-DP-2013-14.pdf|accessdate=24 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714175432/http://www.eria.org/ERIA-DP-2013-14.pdf|archivedate=14 July 2014|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} The six-storey building situated at the junction of [[Serangoon Road]] and Owen Road rapidly collapsed, trapping 50 people beneath the rubble.{{citation|title=Report of the Inquiry into the Collapse of Hotel New World|location=Singapore|publisher=Printed for the [[Government of Singapore]] by Singapore National Printers|year=1987|oclc=24545169|url=http://eservice.nlb.gov.sg/viewer/BookSG/2b6b1c5c-8918-433a-a41e-8d2be8451577}} (Book launch website for: {{cite book|editor=Tommy Koh|date=2006|title=Singapore, the encyclopedia|publisher=Editions Didier Millet|isbn=978-981-4155-63-2}}) Seventeen people were rescued, whereas 33 people were killed. == Background == Frequently referred to as '''Hotel New World''', the building in question was actually the '''Lian Yak Building''' ({{lang-zh|'''联益大厦'''}}), which was completed in 1971 and consisted of six stories and a basement garage. The Hotel New World, previously known as the New Serangoon Hotel until 1984, was the main tenant occupying the top three floors,{{Cite techreport|title=Seventh report of the committee: for the two years ending July 1987|page=13|institution=Standing Committee on Structural Safety|date=September 1987|url=http://www.structural-safety.org/media/41885/162_7th_SCOSS_report_1987.pdf|format=PDF}} and a branch of the Industrial & Commercial Bank (which merged with [[United Overseas Bank]] in 1987) took up the ground level. A nightclub, Universal Neptune Nite-Club and Restaurant, was situated on the second level of the building at the time of the collapse.{{citation|title=《劫后“新”生》第4集- 新世界酒店倒塌|publisher=[[新傳媒私人有限公司]]|year=2015}} The building had previously experienced a poisonous gas leak (caused by [[carbon monoxide]]) in some of the hotel rooms, first hitting the headlines on 30 August 1975, the day after the poisonous gas leak was reported.{{cite web | url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19860316.2.4.8 | title=Gas Ieak made news 10 years ago (Title adjusted due to improper transcription by OCR) | date=16 March 1986 | accessdate=27 September 2018 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171005180339/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19860316.2.4.8 | archive-date=5 October 2017 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }} == Collapse == On 15 March 1986, the building rapidly disintegrated in less than a minute at about {{nowrap|11:25 am}}, leaving little time for anyone within it to make their escape. Witnesses reported hearing an explosion prior to the collapse, but the police ruled out the possibility of a bomb attack. A gas explosion was thought to be a possible cause.{{cite news|title=100 still trapped|author=Philip Lee|publisher=[[The Sunday Times]]|url=http://ourstory.asia1.com.sg/dream/life/headline/lifh12.html|date=16 March 1986|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070816022001/http://ourstory.asia1.com.sg/dream/life/headline/lifh12.html|archivedate=16 August 2007|df=dmy-all}} The collapse was met with shock by many, including the then Prime Minister [[Lee Kuan Yew]] who was quoted as saying that "the collapse of such a building is unprecedented."{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/03/17/world/after-36-hours-2-are-rescued-from-the-ruins-in-singapore.html?sec=travel&n=Top%2FNews%2FWorld%2FCountries+and+Territories%2FSingapore | work=The New York Times | title=After 36 Hours, 2 Are Rescued From The Ruins in Singapore | first=Barbara | last=Crossette | date=17 March 1986 | accessdate=4 May 2010 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612164941/https://www.nytimes.com/1986/03/17/world/after-36-hours-2-are-rescued-from-the-ruins-in-singapore.html?sec=travel&n=Top%2FNews%2FWorld%2FCountries+and+Territories%2FSingapore | archive-date=12 June 2018 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }} === Casualties === Immediately after the collapse, as many as 300 were feared trapped underneath the debris.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/03/15/world/300-trapped-as-hotel-in-singapore-topples.html?n=Top%2FNews%2FWorld%2FCountries+and+Territories%2FSingapore | work=The New York Times | title=300 Trapped as Hotel in Singapore Topples | date=15 March 1986 | accessdate=4 May 2010 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180729051754/https://www.nytimes.com/1986/03/15/world/300-trapped-as-hotel-in-singapore-topples.html?n=Top%2FNews%2FWorld%2FCountries+and+Territories%2FSingapore | archive-date=29 July 2018 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }} Estimates dropped to 100 trapped or missing a day later,{{cite news| url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40710F63B5F0C758DDDAA0894DE484D81&n=Top/News/World/Countries%20and%20Territories/Singapore | work=The New York Times | title=6-Story Hotel Collapses in Singapore; 100 Trapped | date=16 March 1986 | accessdate=4 May 2010}} and then to 60, including 26 hotel staff and 16 bank staff unaccounted for. The figure was finally put at 33 when the official death toll was announced on 22 March 1986 after the end of the rescue effort.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/03/22/world/singapore-toll-put-at-33.html?n=Top%2FNews%2FWorld%2FCountries+and+Territories%2FSingapore | work=The New York Times | title=Singapore Toll Put at 33 | date=22 March 1986 | accessdate=4 May 2010 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180729081334/https://www.nytimes.com/1986/03/22/world/singapore-toll-put-at-33.html?n=Top%2FNews%2FWorld%2FCountries+and+Territories%2FSingapore | archive-date=29 July 2018 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }} Amongst those killed, 23 were Singaporeans, and the other ten foreigners. === Rescue === After the collapse, many passers-by began to try pulling out survivors. They were soon joined by the [[Singapore Civil Defence Force|Singapore Fire Service]] (SFS), the [[Police Tactical Unit (Singapore)|Police Task Force]] of the [[Singapore Police Force]] (SPF) and the [[Singapore Armed Forces]] (SAF). A nearby business, Eagle Piano Company, became a centre for the rescue operation. As there were survivors buried in the rubble, the rescue was a delicate operation. Debris was carefully removed as power saws and drills cut through the rubble. Sound detectors were used to locate survivors beneath the slabs by picking up faint moans and cries. In the first 12 hours, nine people were rescued. At one time, Lieutenant-Colonel Lim Meng Kin (SAF Chief Medical Officer), along with several other SAF medical officers and two doctors from the [[Ministry of Health (Singapore)|Health Ministry]], took turns to crawl through narrow spaces inside the rubble in an effort to provide assistance to trapped survivors, giving [[Intravenous therapy|glucose and saline drips]] to them. Tunnelling experts from Britain, Ireland and Japan who were involved in nearby construction for the (Singapore) Mass Rapid Transit, including Thomas "Tommy" Gallagher, Thomas Mulleary, Patrick "PJ" Gallagher, Michael Prendergast, Michael "Mickey" Scott, and Tan Jin Thong, offered to assist.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/04/27/world/singapore-honors-rescuers.html | work=The New York Times | title=Singapore Honors Rescuers | date=27 April 1986 | access-date=6 February 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160828114523/http://www.nytimes.com/1986/04/27/world/singapore-honors-rescuers.html | archive-date=28 August 2016 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }} They became concerned that the use of heavy machinery would collapse the rubble onto those trapped. Their voluntary efforts, digging 4 tunnels under the rubble, resulted in the rescue of another eight survivors. The tunnelling experts were later honoured by the Singapore government for their efforts. Thomas Mulleary was also nominated for an O.B.E for his rescue work but refused the prestigious honour when the rest of the rescue squad was not included. The last survivor, 30-year-old Chua Kim Choo, was rescued on 18 March 1986, having survived after hiding beneath a table.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/03/19/world/around-the-world-singapore-woman-saved-after-3-days-in-rubble.html?n=Top%2FNews%2FWorld%2FCountries+and+Territories%2FSingapore | work=The New York Times | title=AROUND THE WORLD; Singapore Woman Saved After 3 Days in Rubble | date=19 March 1986 | accessdate=4 May 2010 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612165747/https://www.nytimes.com/1986/03/19/world/around-the-world-singapore-woman-saved-after-3-days-in-rubble.html?n=Top%2FNews%2FWorld%2FCountries+and+Territories%2FSingapore | archive-date=12 June 2018 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }} Following the six-day rescue operation in 21 March, 17 people were rescued, but 33 people lost their lives. == Outcome == === Inquiry === Many potential causes of the accident were investigated. Surviving sections of concrete were tested to ensure they were built to proper construction standards and it was found that they were. The construction work of the underground railway – built by tunnellers who had assisted in the rescue – was investigated, even though the excavations were more than 100 yards from the collapsed building. It was found they had no effect on the building's stability. Also investigated were the various additions made to the building after its initial construction. [[Air conditioning]] systems had been constructed on the roof of the building, the bank had added a large safe, and ceramic tiles had been fixed to the building's exterior, all adding considerably to the building's weight. It was found that the weight of these additions was inconsequential. However, this line of investigation into weight led to the discovery that the original structural engineer had made a serious error in calculating the building's [[structural load]]. The structural engineer had calculated the building's [[Structural load#Live loads|live load]] (the weight of the building's potential inhabitants, furniture, fixtures, and fittings) but the building's [[Structural load#Dead load|dead load]] (the weight of the building itself) was completely omitted from the calculation. This meant that the building as constructed could not support its own weight. Collapsing was only a matter of time. After three different supporting columns failed in the days before the disaster, the other columns—which took on the added weight no longer supported by the failed columns—could not support the building.{{cite episode|title=Hotel Collapse Singapore|series=[[Seconds from disaster]]|season=2|number=9|network=[[National Geographic Channel]]|date=27 September 2005|url=http://natgeotv.com/uk/seconds-from-disaster/about|lang=en|access-date=24 June 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308031118/http://natgeotv.com/uk/seconds-from-disaster/about|archivedate=8 March 2014|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}} According to Channel News Asia, Lian Yak Building was designed by an unqualified draftsman instead of a professional structural engineer. An investigator found that he had over-estimated the dead weight which the columns and walls could support. The draftsman claimed that the building owner Ng Khong Lim, who eventually died in the collapse incident, had appointed him to design Lian Yak Building but Ng directed that building work. The investigator also found that Ng requested to use inferior materials to build Lian Yak Building in order to reduce the cost.{{cite episode|title=Hotel New World Collapse|series=Days of Disaster|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/tv/tvshows/days-of-disaster/hotel-new-world-collapse/1673428.html|access-date=27 February 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227173535/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/tv/tvshows/days-of-disaster/hotel-new-world-collapse/1673428.html|archivedate=27 February 2015|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/lhzb19860919-1.2.15.6.aspx|accessdate=2015-10-17|title=为节省成本 黄康霖修改混凝土成分比例|language=Chinese|date=1986-09-19|first1=Lianhe|last1=Zaobao|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111051506/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/lhzb19860919-1.2.15.6.aspx|archive-date=11 January 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} === Aftermath === On 27 April 1986, the [[Government of Singapore]] honoured five individuals for their assistance in rescue efforts, including three from Ireland, one from Britain, and a local.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/04/27/world/singapore-honors-rescuers.html?n=Top%2FReference%2FTimes+Topics%2FSubjects%2FR%2FRescues | work=The New York Times | title=Singapore Honors Rescuers | date=27 April 1986 | accessdate=4 May 2010 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612162548/https://www.nytimes.com/1986/04/27/world/singapore-honors-rescuers.html?n=Top%2FReference%2FTimes+Topics%2FSubjects%2FR%2FRescues | archive-date=12 June 2018 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }} A dinner was also hosted by the Singapore government on 29 April 1986 for [[SMRT Corporation]] staff involved in the rescue effort, with the then [[Ministry of Communications and Information|Minister of Communications and Information]], [[Yeo Ning Hong]], as the Guest-of-Honour. Following this disaster, buildings built in the 1970s were checked for structural faults, and some of them were declared structurally unsound and had to be evacuated, including the main block of [[Hwa Chong Junior College]] and [[Catholic High School, Singapore|Catholic High School]] campus at Queen Street. {{Cite web|url=https://video.toggle.sg/en/series/tuesday-report-when-the-bell-rings/ep6/524942|title=星期二特写 - 《钟声响起时》第6 集 - 双轨火车|last=|first=|date=21 August 2017|website=video.toggle.sg|access-date=2017-08-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825202840/https://video.toggle.sg/en/series/tuesday-report-when-the-bell-rings/ep6/524942|archive-date=25 August 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The government also introduced tighter regulations on building construction; since 1989, all structural designs are required to be counter-checked by Accredited Checkers.{{cite web|url=http://www.bca.gov.sg/Newsroom/others/pr260699.pdf|format=PDF|title=Update on the Collapse of Roof of School Hall Under Construction at Compassvale Street|publisher=[[Building and Construction Authority]]|date=26 June 1999|access-date=21 October 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070613051605/http://www.bca.gov.sg/Newsroom/others/pr260699.pdf|archive-date=13 June 2007|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The [[Singapore Civil Defence Force]] (SCDF) underwent a significant upgrade, in terms of training and equipment, to improve its readiness in performing complex rescue operations. Five years after the collapse, construction work commenced on the site for a new seven-storey hotel on 28 March 1991. The Fortuna Hotel opened with 85 rooms in 1994.{{cite news|url=http://www.tacboc.ca/LibraryDocs/0,1887,2402.pdf|format=PDF|title=A new world now after hotel collapse|author=Goh Chin Lian|publisher=[[The Straits Times]]|date=15 March 2004}}{{Dead link|date=March 2013}} === In media === In July 1986, singer-songwriter [[Kelvin Tan (musician)|Kelvin Tan]] contributed to ''BigO'' magazine's ''Nothing on the Radio'' cassette the song "Seen the End", after spending two nights at the former Hotel New World site.{{cite news|title=Sounds like Nothing on the Radio|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19860704-1.2.68.11.4.aspx|accessdate=30 September 2014|agency=The Straits Times|publisher=Singapore Press Holdings|date=4 July 1986|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006091830/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19860704-1.2.68.11.4.aspx|archive-date=6 October 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} In 1990, the disaster was re-enacted in the Chinese-language television series ''[[Finishing Line]]'' (出人头地), which was aired on SBC 8 (now [[MediaCorp Channel 8]]). On 25 September 2003, the disaster was featured in the first episode of the second season of the television series ''True Courage'', which was broadcast on MediaCorp TV Channel 5 (now [[MediaCorp Channel 5]]). A Chinese-language version of the series, titled ''True Courage'' (逆境勇者), was also on aired on MediaCorp TV Channel 8 (now MediaCorp Channel 8). On 27 September 2005, ''Seconds From Disaster'' portrayed the disaster in the episode "Hotel Collapse Singapore". Instead of the actual site, the program used an image of the area around 88 Syed Alwi Road (at the corner of Kampon Kapor Road) as the basis for a computer-generated reconstruction of the building and its collapse. The episode was retelecast in Singapore on 16 September 2007 via [[StarHub TV]]. In February 2015, ''Days of Disasters'' also portrayed the disaster in the episode "Hotel New World Collapse".{{cite news|title=Hotel New World Collapse Video (Channel NewsAsia)|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/tv/tvshows/days-of-disaster/hotel-new-world-collapse/1673428.html|accessdate=27 February 2015|agency=Channel NewsAsia|publisher=MediaCorp Pte Ltd.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150226103911/http://www.channelnewsasia.com/tv/tvshows/days-of-disaster/hotel-new-world-collapse/1673428.html|archive-date=26 February 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} It was also featured in the drama ''[[The Journey: Our Homeland]]''. == See also == * [[Highland Towers collapse|1993 Highland Towers disaster]] in neighbouring [[Malaysia]] == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * {{cite web |url=http://www.mindef.gov.sg/joint/hqmc/ops_hnw.html |title=SAF Medical Services: Hotel New World 1986 |publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (Singapore)]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061118021559/http://www.mindef.gov.sg/joint/hqmc/ops_hnw.html |archive-date=2006-11-18}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.scdf.gov.sg/General/Information/Local_Major_Incidents/collapse_hotel_new_world.html |title=Local Major Incidents: Collapse of Hotel New World |date=6 Nov 2006 |publisher=[[Singapore Civil Defence Force]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070115235011/http://www.scdf.gov.sg/General/Information/Local_Major_Incidents/collapse_hotel_new_world.html |archive-date=2007-01-15}} * {{cite web |url=http://infopedia.nlb.gov.sg/articles/SIP_783_2004-12-31.html |title=Singapore Infopedia: Hotel New World collapse |date=2002 |publisher=[[National Library Board]] |location=Singapore |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061231211118/http://infopedia.nlb.gov.sg/articles/SIP_783_2004-12-31.html |archive-date=2006-12-31}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hotel New World Disaster}} 1986 events]]

{{about|the Goth subculture festival|the science-fiction convention|CONvergence}} {{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=August 2012}} {{Notability|Events|date=August 2012}} }}
{{Infobox Convention | name = Convergence | image =File:Convergence Goth festival.jpg | caption = | status = Active | genre = [[Goth subculture|Goth]] | venue = | location = [[North America]] | first = 1995 | last = | organizer = | filing = | website = http://www.altgothic.com/ }}
'''Convergence''' (sometimes referenced as C*) is the annual [[net.goth]] party run by and for members of the [[alt.gothic]] and alt.gothic.fashion [[newsgroups|newsgroup]], and other related Usenet newsgroups. Started in 1995, it is a chance for [[net.goth]]s and others who normally only meet on the [[Internet]] to meet. Events at Convergence typically included live bands and [[nightclub|club]] nights, bazaars, fashion, art shows, panels, and tours of goth-themed locales in the host city.
== Location ==
Convergence is a "floating" event. The location for each year voted on by the [[net.goth]] community in response to proposals by volunteer committees. So far all have taken place in [[North America]].
Past Convergences have been held in: *Convergence 1 (June 23–24, 1995): [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] *Convergence 2 (August 9–11, 1996): [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]] *Convergence 3 (August 1–3, 1997): [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]] *Convergence 4 (August 21–23, 1998): [[Toronto]] *Convergence 5 (April 2–4, 1999): [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]] *Convergence 6 (May 26–29, 2000): [[Seattle, Washington|Seattle]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c07newyork/thurs.html Convergence 7]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.altgothic.com/c07newyork/thurs.html|title=C7 Proposal, NYC: Thursday|website=www.altgothic.com|access-date=2017-08-31}}</ref> (August 17–19, 2001): [[New York City, New York|New York]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c08montreal/ Convergence 8] (May 31-June 2, 2002): [[Montreal]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c09lasvegas/ Convergence 9] (April 25–27, 2003): [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c10chicago/ Convergence 10] (May 7–9, 2004): [[Chicago, IL|Chicago, Illinois]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050928202843/http://www.convergence11.com/ Convergence 11] (April 22–25, 2005): [[San Diego, California|San Diego]] *Convergence 12 (April 13–16, 2006): [[New Orleans, LA|New Orleans, Louisiana]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c13portland/ Convergence 13] (May 25–27, 2007): [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]] *[http://www.c14ybor.com/ Convergence 14] (August 8–11, 2008): [[Ybor City]] ([[Tampa, FL]]) *[http://convergence15.com/ Convergence 15] (July 17–20, 2009): [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c16slc/ Convergence 16] (August 13–16, 2010): [[Park City, Utah]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c17czm/ Convergence 17] (June 24–26, 2011): [[Cozumel, Mexico]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c18buf/ Convergence 18] (June 15–17, 2012): [[Buffalo, New York]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130530040401/http://www.gatheringovbats.net/cxix Convergence 19] (April 18–22, 2013): [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c20chi/ Convergence 20] (April 25–27, 2014): [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c21hol/ Convergence 21] (May 1–3, 2015): [[Hollywood, CA|Hollywood]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c22nol/ Convergence 22] (March 25–27, 2016): [[New Orleans, LA|New Orleans]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c23dfw/ Convergence 23] (May 19-21, 2017): [[Dallas, TX|Dallas, Texas]] *[http://www.altgothic.com/c24dtw/ Convergence 24] (April 27-29, 2018): [[Detroit, MI|Detroit, Michigan]]
== Attendance == Convergence was initially proposed and planned by two long-time members of the [[alt.gothic]] [[newsgroup]] hierarchy, at the time residents of [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]], as an international gathering of members of the newsgroups and related [[net.goth]] groups. It was conceived as an opportunity for those who had previously known each other primarily or exclusively through [[Internet]] forums, to meet and get to know each other in person.
There has been considerable debate regarding the extent to which the event should reach out to other on-line gothic communities, as well as members of local non-[[Internet]]-based [[Goth subculture|gothic]] scenes. Some planning committees have made efforts to expand the scope of the event; while others have made similar efforts to restrict advertising to predominantly the founding [[net.goth]] communities.
Attendance ranged over the years usually between 300-800, but attendance spiked at Convergence 13 to approximately 1,500.
== Organization ==
There is no formal Convergence organization per se. Since shortly after its inception, the bidding and voting process has been managed by a more-or-less consistent group of volunteers, known informally as the C*b*l, composed of several of the longest-term participants in the [[alt.gothic]] newsgroups. The C*b*l is widely recognized as having made some of the most substantial contributions to maintaining Convergence, and are among its most frequent attendees. The group also maintains the official Convergence website, and provides organizational and informational assistance to host committees.
Each Convergence is organized and run by an [[ad hoc]] volunteer committee. Committees typically consist of residents of the host city, a large percentage of whom are expected to be active participants on alt.gothic or related [[net.goth]] groups.
==See also== {{Commons category|Convergence (goth festival)}} *[[List of electronic music festivals]] *[[List of gothic festivals]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.altgothic.com/wiki/index.php/Convergence Convergence website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061214232823/http://www.virulent.org/converg4/past.html A Brief History of Convergence website] * [http://www.c14ybor.com/ Convergence 14 website] * [http://convergence15.com/ Convergence 15 website] * [http://www.altgothic.com/c16slc/ Convergence 16 website] * [http://www.altgothic.com/c20chi/ Convergence 20 website] * [http://convergence.livejournal.com/ Convergence live journal] {{Electronic music events}}
